metadata.case_name: Hans Muller v. Superintendent, Presidency Jail, Calcutta

facts.text: Petitioner Hans Muller, a citizen of West Germany, arrested by Calcutta Police on 18th September 1954 and placed under preventive detention by West Bengal Government under section 3(1) of Preventive Detention Act 1950 for making arrangements for his expulsion from India.

Grounds of detention served on petitioner on 22nd September 1954, second ground stating he is foreigner under Foreigners Act 1946 and detention required under section 3(1)(b) PDA until expulsion order by Central Government.
On 19th September 1954, petitioner wrote to Consul-General of West Germany at Calcutta requesting early interview, which was granted.
On 21st September 1954, petitioner wrote to West Bengal Government requesting immediate repatriation and arrangements for transmission out of India.

On 9th October 1954, Calcutta Police handed petitioner's passport to West German Consul at Consul's request; passport issued by West German Government on 27th November 1953 with visas including Indian visa conditioned 'while the passport is valid'; Consul endorsed 'Valid only for the return voyage to the Federal Republic of Germany until the 8th January 1955'.

On 9th October 1954, West German Government wrote to West Bengal Government stating warrant of arrest issued against petitioner in West Germany for frauds, proceedings pending; similar charges in Lebanon and Egypt; requested provisional warrant for detention till extradition; arranged repatriation by German boat KANDELfels arriving 19th October; expenses borne by West German Government.

Secretary to West Bengal Government noted: 'I suppose there would be no objection to our keeping Muller in detention till the 19th instant. We must issue order of his release as soon as his boat is ready to sail.'
West Bengal Government had no power to deport; only Central Government could; no expulsion orders by Central Government till 20th October 1954.
Petitioner applied to High Court of Calcutta for habeas corpus under section 491 CrPC on 20th October 1954.
High Court dismissed petition on 10th December 1954.
Petitioner filed present petition to Supreme Court under Article 32 on 10th January 1955.
Central Government made and signed expulsion order but held in abeyance pending Supreme Court decision.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 3(1)(b) of Preventive Detention Act 1950 is ultra vires Constitution on grounds: (a) contravenes Articles 21 and 22; (b) contravenes Article 14; (c) beyond legislative competence of Parliament.
Whether section 3(1)(b) PDA is a law of preventive detention within meaning of Article 22(3), or contravenes Article 22(1) and (2).
Whether detention order made in bad faith.
Whether State Government can detain under s.3(1)(b) PDA in anticipation of Central Government's expulsion order.
Distinction between expulsion under Foreigners Act and extradition under Extradition Act; whether detention for expulsion can be used to facilitate extradition without formalities.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 3(1)(b) PDA ultra vires as contravenes Articles 21 and 22.
Section 3(1)(b) PDA ultra vires as contravenes Article 14.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14 Constitution; definition of foreigner in Foreigners Act s.2(a)

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 3(1)(b) beyond legislative competence of Parliament.
Section 3(1)(b) not law of preventive detention under Article 22(3); contravenes Article 22(1),(2).
Detention in bad faith: real object to hand over to West German authorities via boat without extradition; political persecution.
State Government cannot detain for expulsion as only Central Government can expel; arrangements must follow expulsion order.

respondent_arguments.text: Legislative competence from Entry 9 Union List (preventive detention connected with Foreign Affairs), Entry 10 (Foreign Affairs), Entry 17 (aliens), Entry 19 (expulsion).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Entries 9,10,17,19 Union List; Entry 3 Concurrent List

respondent_arguments.text: Section 3(1)(b) complies with Articles 21,22; enacted to align Foreigners Act s.4(1) with Constitution.
Detention for expulsion is preventive; prevents breach/evasion.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Foreigners Act ss.3(2)(c),11(1); Preventive Detention Act

respondent_arguments.text: Expulsion order made but held in abeyance; bad faith question academic.
Expulsion and extradition distinct; Government discretion to choose expulsion.

court_reasoning.text: Legislative competence clear under Entry 9 Union List (preventive detention for reasons connected with Foreign Affairs) read with Entry 10; widest scope to entries; affects relations with foreign countries.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislation depriving foreigners of liberty without trial brings Union into relation with foreign country.

court_reasoning.text: Complies with Articles 21,22; procedure established by law; Preventive Detention Act framed with limitations in view.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Detention for expulsion is preventive as prevents evasion; ancillary to expulsion power.

court_reasoning.text: State Government empowered to detain in anticipation of expulsion; necessary for arrangements including reference to Centre; wide discretion needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unless State can act in anticipation, might be too late.

court_reasoning.text: No Article 14 violation; reasonable classification of foreigners excluding certain British subjects; petitioner not aggrieved as not British subject.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only aggrieved persons can challenge under Article 32.

court_reasoning.text: Good faith upheld; no evidence change of purpose post-Consul letter; Secretary note not Government mind.
Expulsion under Foreigners Act distinct from extradition; unfettered discretion to expel foreigner as free man; no obligation to extradite even if request.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expelled leaves free man; extradited remains in custody; Foreigners Act not governed by Extradition Act.

holdings.text: Section 3(1)(b) Preventive Detention Act and section 3(2)(c) Foreigners Act intra vires Constitution.
Detention under s.3(1)(b) by State Government valid even in anticipation of Central expulsion order.
Detention not in bad faith; expulsion and extradition distinct procedures.

precedents_cited.relevance: Classification of foreigners reasonable and does not offend Article 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Earlier cases on locus standi under Article 32
precedents_cited.relevance: Only aggrieved persons can impugn legislation.

statutes_cited.relevance: Confers expulsion power on Central Government; ancillary detention preventive; unfettered discretion; definition of foreigner.

outcome.summary: Court upheld vires of section 3(1)(b) Preventive Detention Act and related provisions; detention valid and not in bad faith; petition dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "Giving Entry 9 its widest range we find it impossible to hold that legislation that deals with the right of a State to keep foreigners under preventive detention without trial does not bring the Union into relation with a foreign country."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The most effective method of preventing a breach of the order and ensuring that it is duly obeyed is by arresting and detaining the person ordered to be expelled until proper arrangements for the expulsion can be made."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies detention as preventive for expulsion.

key_quotes.text: "In the case of expulsion, no idea of punishment is involved... the person expelled leaves India a free man."
key_quotes.speaker: court
